body: Thanks for the report, I can reproduce this issue. It seems like `eslint-scope` isn't getting compiled to ES5 with the new build setup.

issue.title: Build: compile deps to ES5 when generating browser file (fixes #11504)

labels.name: build
labels.description: This change relates to ESLint's build process

labels.name: accepted
labels.description: There is consensus among the team that this change meets the criteria for inclusion

labels.name: archived due to age
labels.description: This issue has been archived; please open a new issue for any further discussion

repository.name: eslint
repository.description: Find and fix problems in your JavaScript code.

issue.body:
<!--
    ESLint adheres to the [JS Foundation Code of Conduct](https://js.foundation/community/code-of-conduct).
-->

**What is the purpose of this pull request? (put an "X" next to item)**

[x] Bug fix (https://github.com/eslint/eslint/issues/11504)

<!--
    If the item you've checked above has a template, please paste the template questions below and answer them. (If this pull request is addressing an issue, you can just paste a link to the issue here instead.)
-->

<!--
    Please ensure your pull request is ready:

    - Read the pull request guide (https://eslint.org/docs/developer-guide/contributing/pull-requests)
    - Include tests for this change
    - Update documentation for this change (if appropriate)
-->

<!--
    The following is required for all pull requests:
-->

**What changes did you make? (Give an overview)**

This updates the webpack config to compile dependencies to ES5, to ensure that the final output file is runnable in ES5 browsers. It tests this behavior by running ESLint on the output file.

**Is there anything you'd like reviewers to focus on?**

Nothing in particular

body: Can you paste the whole line? Thanks.
Did you build ESLint by yourself?

Yes, I pulled the current master branch and build ESLint by running
```sh
npm run webpack
```

Well, this is a bug from [`core-js`](https://github.com/zloirock/core-js/).

Look at Line 4795 in the picture you gave. There is a comment which is `RegExp constructor can alter flags and IsRegExp works correct with...`, and I found it: https://github.com/zloirock/core-js/search?q=RegExp+constructor+can+alter+flags+and+IsRegExp+works+correct+with&unscoped_q=RegExp+constructor+can+alter+flags+and+IsRegExp+works+correct+with .

It seems that we're using `core-js` v2, but `core-js` v3 is developing now, so I'm not sure if they fixed it.
It's not a bug from `core-js`, it's a bug it regexp pattern, wrapper just calls internally original `RegExp` constructor with the passed pattern.
recently we are using `/u` flag in regex -- it may be related to this. can you see the error stack?

@aladdin-add You are right!

It is the `createGlobalLinebreakMatcher` function in [ast-utils.js](https://github.com/eslint/eslint/blob/1f715a20c145d8ccc38f3310afccd838495d09d4/lib/util/ast-utils.js#L401). The `u`-flag was added in #11422.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/25029871/54487173-03a44380-4893-11e9-87de-bc8142daecdf.png)
 
This whole "syntax error" thing threw me off; for some reason I assumed this whole time that the error occurs during the parsing phase of the file ðŸ˜©ðŸ¤¦â€â™‚ï¸
I was under the impression that babel can polyfill the behavior of unicode regexes. Is that not the case?

Hm, it can in principle ([Babel Regex](https://babeljs.io/docs/en/babel-plugin-transform-unicode-regex)). But I think there would be limitations for usages like
```js
return new RegExp(LINEBREAK_MATCHER.source, "gu");
// or
new RegExp(somePatternVariable, someFlagVariable)
```
because it can't really manipulate the content of those variables, right?
I thought it would polyfill the `RegExp` constructor itself to handle those cases at runtime.

Babel apparently uses the *regexpu* package to do the transform which has this exact [limitation](https://www.npmjs.com/package/regexpu#known-limitations). I couldn't find any polyfill of the `RegExp` contructor for the `u`-flag unfortunately.

issue.title: discussion: what sort of minimum versions we need to support?

labels.name: accepted
labels.description: There is consensus among the team that this change meets the criteria for inclusion
